I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Macroeconomic context and challenges. Bangladesh has achieved robust economic 
growth, averaging more than 6.0% since 2011 and recording 8.1% for FY2019. Such strong 
growth  has  been  driven  by  steady  expansion  and  surge  in  export-oriented  manufacturing 
industries, such as ready-made garment, textile, leather, and food processing.1 The service sector 
is also growing, including retail, health care and tourism. Despite sustained growth during the past 
decade, the country faces tremendous challenge in developing a skilled, competitive workforce 
that can meet emerging skills needs in the local and global labor markets. The working-age 
population is expanding fast from 87 million in 2011 to 119 million by 2026, with 2 million potential 
new entrants to the labor force every year. More than half of the labor force have only primary 
education or less; and less than 4.0% of the working-age population (aged 15–59) had received 
any technical or vocational training.2 Youth unemployment rate has risen from 4.0% in 1991 to 
more  than  10%  currently.  To  sustain  the  country’s  growth  path  and  reap  the  benefit  of 
demographic dividend, the country needs to invest in its human capital resources and develop a 
well-trained  and  highly-skilled  workforce.  Rapid  technology  advances  are  also  affecting 
Bangladesh industries, altering the nature of jobs which demand higher levels of technical and 
cognitive skills while reducing demand for low-skilled jobs.3  
 
2.  Demand for modernizing technical education and skills development. To develop 
job-ready and demand-responsive skills among youth, modern technical education and training 
systems are necessary. However, the capacity and quality of technical education and skills 
training in Bangladesh are inadequate. First, curriculum is largely theory-based and has limited 
relevance to today’s requirements in industries. Second, training facilities and equipment are too 
outdated to deliver current or emerging technical skills, and the overall capacity is insufficient to 
accommodate increasing numbers of youth to be trained. Third, the supply of qualified trainers is 
limited, and the existing trainers have not updated their pedagogic and technical skills to adapt 
today’s training requirements. Finally, there is lack of credible assessment and certification 
systems to ensure the quality of training systems. Consequently, technical education, including 
polytechnics, has not led to successful employment, showing a job placement rate of less than 
50%. Female participation is also limited with only 24% of enrollment in technical and vocational 
education and training (TVET) being female. To ensure that young men and women are equipped 
with requisite skills in line with labor market demands, significant improvements are needed in the 
TVET system as well as the overall skills development system. Improving the TVET system is 
important for ensuring inclusive development, as the trainees in technical institutes are mostly 
from low socioeconomic backgrounds, who may not be able to pursue a higher education. 
 
3.  Asian Development Bank’s assistance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been 
supporting the Government of Bangladesh in its technical education and skills development 
initiatives through the Skills Development Project (2008–2017) and the Skills for Employment 
Investment  Program  (SEIP;  2014–2024).4 The  aim  of  these  projects  was  to  increase  the

employability and productivity of the youth entering the labor force. In particular, SEIP has: (i) 
expanded the capacity of the country’s training system by partnering with the private sector; (ii) 
improved the relevance of training by directly aligning with industry demands; and (iii) enhanced 
the quality of trainers and quality assurance systems. Another TA has also supported SEIP to 
improve fiduciary management among implementing partners.5 Based on these achievements, 
the  government  has  requested  additional  interventions  to  further  upgrade  and  modernize 
technical education and training systems, and to elevate the levels of skills training to meet the 
increasing demand for advanced skills requirements. Building upon the experiences and lessons 
of the recent skills development interventions, ADB will help the government in designing strategic 
technical education and skills development projects catering to specific industry’s demand for 
advanced skills. 
 
4.  To ensure successful outcomes of ADB support, it is critical to enhance the capacity and 
competencies of executing and implementing agencies in order to ensure quality project designs, 
effective  project  implementation,  sound  financial  management,  and  overall  portfolio 
performance.6 It is also essential to consolidate and share the lessons and good practices 
together with dedicated capacity building for project designs and implementation. The proposed 
transaction technical assistance (TA) facility would bridge capability gaps, apply best practices, 
and foster innovative solutions for common challenges in the sector. The support will be provided 
through the provision of incremental consulting services to enhance project preparatory and 
implementation capacity. The TA facility is aligned with ADB Strategy 2030 in addressing poverty, 
reducing inequalities, supporting gender equality, and strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity. The TA facility is listed in the country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 2020–
2022, with the title Preparing Technical Education Modernization Project.7     
 
5.  The transaction TA facility will provide project preparation support, capacity building, and 
policy advice to two ensuing projects, comprising (i) Technical Education Modernization Project 
and (ii) Second Skills for Employment Investment Program. Both projects are in the technical 
education and skills development subsector. The TA facility approach is suitable as it will enhance 
project preparation efficiency and improve project implementation readiness.  In particular, the TA 
facility will: (i) allow the pool of experts and consultants to be mobilized for due diligence activities; 
(ii) facilitate the learning of lessons in project processing and implementation across projects; (iii) 
create synergies among the larger pool of experts through common expertise; and (iv) strengthen 
coordination among technical inputs and capacity building arrangement. Overall, the TA facility 
will reduce transaction costs compared to resources required for separate stand-alone transaction 
TA projects. 
 
6.  The transaction TA facility will also provide capacity building to two ongoing projects, 
comprising Skills for Employment Investment Program Tranche 2 and Tranche 3, as required and 
agreed with respective executing and implementing agencies. 8 Given the varying and evolving 
implementation  capacities,  ongoing  skills  development  projects  often  face  unanticipated 
challenges such as in the areas of procurement, financial management, and safeguards which

require resources for assessments or mitigation measures. Technical and training support will be 
provided to also ensure project sustainability and transfer of capacity and knowledge. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Improved design quality and readiness of projects achieved. Technical 
expertise will be provided to support background studies, project design and readiness of the two 
projects (para. 5) for potential ADB financing. The scope of activities will cover (i) analytical studies 
such as sector assessments, demand assessments, and stakeholder analysis as appropriate for 
each ensuing project; (ii) feasibility studies, such are conceptual technical designs, as required 
for  ensuing  projects;  (iii)  development  of  results  frameworks  or  monitoring  and  evaluation 
frameworks; (iv) economic and financial assessments, and social, gender, and poverty analysis; 
(v) safeguard assessments including environment and social safeguards; and (vi) due diligence 
in financial management, procurement, plus other institutional arrangements for executing and 
implementing  agencies.  The  output  will  also  support  project  readiness  through  advance 
procurement activities for the ensuing projects.   
 
8.  Output 2: International best practice and innovative solutions mainstreamed in 
project design and implementation. Technical advisory and capacity building will be provided 
to executing and implementing agencies and relevant stakeholders to share international best 
practices and technology-based innovative solutions. Lessons learned from past interventions will 
also be analyzed to inform project designs and practices. These practices will be incorporated 
into ongoing as well as ensuing projects. The topics will cover such areas as teacher training, 
authentic practical training, industry linkage and partnership, international twinning arrangement, 
and online open learning for technical education and skills development. Support will be provided 
through dialogues, workshops, and national and overseas study visits.  
 
9.  Output  3:  Capacity  of  executing  and  implementing  agencies  on  planning, 
implementation and management strengthened. Technical expertise and other support will be 
provided  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  executing  and  implementing  agencies  of  technical 
education and skills development projects for successful implementation and sustainability. 
Support will be provided for critical areas, such as planning for modern technical education, 
setting up quality training facilities, specifications of quality training equipment, establishment of 
effective monitoring and evaluation systems, ensuring financial management and procurement 
capacity for timely implementation and sustainability, gender mainstreaming, and safeguards. 
Along with expert advice, seminars or workshops will be offered across multiple projects.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $525,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. The TA facility scope is expected to expand to cover other additional 
activities, consistent with the TA’s outputs and activities, and be replenished from time to time as 
required and additional funds are available.  
 
11.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space, workshop facilities, office supplies, secretarial and coordination assistance, and other in-
kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance ensuing projects.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The Finance Division in the Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency of the TA 
facility. ADB, through the South Asia Human and Social Development Division (SAHS), will 
administer the TA facility and will work closely with the executing and implementing departments 
for the ongoing and planned projects. ADB will be responsible for the recruitment, management, 
and administration of all consultants financed by the TA facility. ADB will inform the relevant 
government agencies of selected consultants prior to their mobilization.  
 
13.  The  TA  facility  will  be  implemented  over  3  years,  from  June  2020  to  June  2023. 
Disbursement under the TA facility will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).

15.  Consulting services. The TA facility will initially provide 45 person-months’ consultant 
inputs (14 person-months international and 31 person-months national) to support the preparation 
of ensuing projects and implementation of ongoing projects. The consultants will be recruited 
using individual consultant selection method and deployed based on the requirements of each 
project being prepared or implemented. Individual consultant selection, rather than firm selection, 
is  considered  appropriate,  because  the  TA  facility  involves  multiple  activities  that  are  not 
necessarily interdependent and will require a varied range of consultants and services. ADB will 
engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.9  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Bangladesh for Supporting Technical Education and Skills Development Facility 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.
